title-group.subtitle: Books and Films You May Have Missed

article-meta.aff: 1American Labor Education Center, Talent, OR, USA

fn.p: This column is adapted from World Wide Work, written by Matt Witt, and published eight times a year by the American Labor Education Center, an independent nonprofit that operates www.TheWorkSite.org, a free website that provides downloadable tools and tips for educators and activists.

sec.title: 23 Shades of Black
sec.p: This mystery novel contains elements rarely found in the genre—the main protagonist is one of the first Latinas in the New York Police Department, she faces moral dilemmas as she is expected to enforce laws on immigration and drug use, and a murder investigation eventually leads her to corporate crime involving toxic waste.

sec.title: 99 to 1
sec.p: A short, elementary guide to wealth inequality in America also gives ideas on what to do about it.

sec.title: Affluence & Influence
sec.p: An academic applies statistical analysis to compare actual policy decisions by the federal government to policy preferences expressed at the time by various economic segments of the population. His results quantify the fact that political decisions generally correlate with the views of wealthy Americans and not with the views of a majority of the population.

sec.title: Arctic Voices
sec.p: The Arctic region, so important to the earth as an ecosystem, is at a tipping point as global corporations seek to extract its resources at all costs, according to these writings by thirty-nine scientists, activists, journalists, and native leaders.

sec.title: Beautiful Trouble
sec.p: Grassroots movements are moving beyond rallies with speakers and other often passive and ineffective forms of protest to create a wide range of actions that are fun and challenging to the corporate culture and political system. This excellent toolkit, with contributions from dozens of leading activists, describes new tactics, theories of effective action, case studies, and groups that use political theater in organizing. All of the material is available online as well as in the printed book.

sec.title: Do You Dream in Color?
sec.p: A successful opera singer who has been blind from birth presents a well-written memoir that gives a good picture of what it’s like to navigate growing up, school, the workplace, and personal relationships in the sighted world.

sec.title: Drone Warfare
sec.p: The human rights leader takes a comprehensive look at drones—who makes them, how they are being used, how they may come back to haunt the United States once others have them, and what activists are doing to confront this new technology.

sec.title: Electoral Dysfunction
sec.p: More than fifty million Americans are not registered to vote despite being eligible. About a third of those who are registered don’t vote. Wealthy Americans vote at a far higher rate than working people. This book explains that elections in America do not reflect the will of the people, and that Republican governors and legislatures like it that way. They have been systematically passing state laws to reduce voting participation by people of lower income, students, seniors, people with disabilities, and people of color. Bassetti suggests genuine reforms that would make it easier for all Americans to be heard.

sec.title: Ellavut
sec.p: By Ann Fienup-Riordan and Alice Rearden
Dozens of native Yup’ik elders in Alaska share their experiences and wisdom about how humans can get along with our environment and with each other.

sec.title: Exit, Civilian
sec.p: A collection of moving poetry focuses on what it’s like to be in prison.

sec.title: Fuel on the Fire
sec.p: Many Americans believed from the start that the war on Iraq was designed to get control of that country’s oil for global corporations. An investigative reporter sifted through unreleased documents and conducted interviews to show how the oil takeover was accomplished even as officials were denying that it was taking place.

sec.title: Green Illusions
sec.p: No energy policy will succeed unless it focuses on ways to reduce consumption. New technologies to produce “green” energy will not provide the problem-free panacea that some Americans expect.

sec.title: Labor Rising
sec.p: Edited by Daniel Katz and Richard A. Greenwald

The Occupy movement and battles over workers’ rights in Wisconsin, Ohio, and other states have prompted a fresh look at the future of unions and other forms of worker organizing. This collection contains two dozen essays by critics, activists, professors, and organizers.

sec.title: Merchants of Doubt
sec.p: By Naomi Oreskes and Erik M. Conway

The emergence of industry-funded scientists who deny the existence of climate change is not an accident. Many of the same people were paid in the past to sow doubt about the effects of smoking, acid rain, and depletion of the ozone layer.

sec.title: New California Writing 2012
sec.p: A generally high-quality collection of stories, nonfiction, and poems includes a wide variety of styles and perspectives.

sec.title: None of Us Were Like This Before
sec.p: Phillips documents the human stories of American soldiers who have engaged in torture and are permanently damaged themselves.

sec.title: Pineros
sec.p: Through the use of contractors for reforestation and forest “management,” the federal government has become one of the largest exploiters of (often undocumented) Latino workers in certain regions, according to this report based on interviews and government documents.

sec.title: The Case for Sanctions Against Israel
sec.p: Activists from Israel, the United States, and other countries give their views on an international movement to pressure the Israeli government to end the occupation of Palestinian land, support self-determination for the Palestinian people, and ensure full equality for Palestinians in Israel.

sec.title: The Emperor Has No Clothes
sec.p: This useful book analyzes ways that many whites resist learning about racism and suggests how to overcome that resistance in workshops and classrooms.

sec.title: The Evening Hour
sec.p: An exceptional novel focuses on a young nursing home worker whose Appalachian homeland is being ravaged by the coal industry. The characters are intriguing and complex, and the story is fresh and generally free of clichés.

sec.title: The Journey to Tahrir
sec.p: Edited by Jeannie Sowers and Chris Toensing

The 2011 uprising in Egypt had roots in the experience over many years of women, students, workers, fishing communities, gay people, artists, and many others. This collection of essays provides the details for those who want to dig deeper.

sec.title: The Republic of Nature
sec.p: An innovative textbook retells some selected stories from U.S. history through an environmentalist’s eyes. Chapters focus on the cotton industry and slavery, the building of the transcontinental railroad, the building of the first atomic bomb, and much more.

sec.title: The World We Found
sec.p: Four women were best friends as young radicals in India. This novel follows their very different lives since then as they attempt a reunion.

sec.title: Trevor
sec.p: An eighty-six-page novel for teenagers centers on a boy who is driven to attempt suicide because other students don’t accept the fact that he is gay.

sec.title: Gayby
sec.p: A playful comedy directed by a gay man features two longtime friends—a straight woman and gay man—who decide to have a baby together.

sec.title: Heist
sec.p: Perhaps the best film yet about the roots of today’s economic conditions in the United States, domination of public policy by corporate interests, and grassroots resistance that has emerged in the past few years. Other filmmakers should follow the example of the producers of this film who provide it in three lengths—seventy-six, fifty-eight, and twenty-two minutes—for maximum usefulness in local organizing.

sec.title: Pink Ribbons, Inc.
sec.p: Based on a book with the same name, this ninety-eight-minute documentary is quite timely given the recent controversy generated by the Komen Foundation’s blacklisting of Planned Parenthood. Millions of well-meaning people have donated money and volunteer hours to “races for the cure” and other activities that supposedly fund breast cancer research. The corporate sponsors of these “pink” activities, including drug and cosmetic companies, enhance their brand while ensuring that the research does not target the substances in the environment, workplaces, and consumer products that cause cancer in the first place. The film includes interviews with scientists and cancer prevention experts as well as the heads of Komen, the Avon Foundation, and other key sponsors of the pink establishment.

sec.title: Pipe Dreams
sec.p: A thirty-nine-minute documentary features ranchers in Nebraska and South Dakota telling why they oppose the Keystone XL tar sands oil pipeline. They explain why they believe the pipeline will actually raise gas prices, contaminate water supplies, and lead to spills that are far more difficult to clean up than conventional oil spills. They say they are being given no choice but to sell right-of-way access, or else the Canadian pipeline company will get U.S. courts to grant that right through eminent domain. A Laborers union official says in an interview that he does not believe there are significant safety concerns and that constructing the pipeline will create jobs.

sec.title: We Are Legion
sec.p: As global corporations increasingly depend on the Internet, “hacktivism” that interferes with their operations may become as important in pressuring them to act responsibly as strikes once were in the industrial age. This fascinating ninety-three-minute documentary traces the evolution of the “Anonymous” movement as participants decide to put their hacker skills to work in support of WikiLeaks, Arab Spring, and other causes.

sec.title: We Are Not Ghosts
sec.p: A fifty-two-minute documentary features African-Americans in Detroit who are trying to revitalize their neighborhoods through community businesses, urban food gardens, place-based schools, and the arts.
